attributes.title: What is women's G-spot? (is it exist?) | Know Everything about Female Sexual Anatomy
attributes.metaDesc:
Have you ever been confused about the anatomy down there? If you’re either having intercourse or making love to somebody with a vulva or you own one yourself? 

Note: Vulva ===> the outer part of female genitals. 



In this article we’re going to talk about all you need to know about female anatomy.  



And make sure you read till the end of the article because I’m going to talk about what exactly is this infamous G-⁠spot and what should you know about it. 



The specifics of anatomy it’s important to understand how we develop. For simplicity’s sake, in this article I’m going to refer to anybody with a penis as a male, anybody with a vulva as a female.  



When a fetus is getting developed in the uterus. So when someone’s pregnant and their baby is developing during the first eight weeks we don’t have any genitals. The fetus has two distinct things that will eventually develop into either a female or male anatomy and that is a genital tubrical and a urogenital sinus.  



At about ten weeks, the fetus starts developing male or female external genitalia, depending on what genes the baby has. So if they’re an XX, they’re going to develop into a female, and if they’re an XY, they’re going to develop into a male.

body.content:
Have you ever been confused about the anatomy down there? If you’re either having intercourse or making love to somebody with a vulva or you own one yourself? 

Note: Vulva ===> the outer part of female genitals. 

 

In this article we’re going to talk about all you need to know about female anatomy.  

 

And make sure you read till the end of the article because I’m going to talk about what exactly is this infamous G-⁠spot and what should you know about it. 

 

The specifics of anatomy it’s important to understand how we develop. For simplicity’s sake, in this article I’m going to refer to anybody with a penis as a male, anybody with a vulva as a female.  

 

When a fetus is getting developed in the uterus. So when someone’s pregnant and their baby is developing during the first eight weeks we don’t have any genitals. The fetus has two distinct things that will eventually develop into either a female or male anatomy and that is a genital tubrical and a urogenital sinus.  

 

At about ten weeks, the fetus starts developing male or female external genitalia, depending on what genes the baby has. So if they’re an XX, they’re going to develop into a female, and if they’re an XY, they’re going to develop into a male. 

     

 

The genital tubrical, as you can see here, develops into the head of the penis in the male and the head of the clitoris in the female. Because these structures develop from the original eurogenital sinus and genital tubrical that were identical in both pheuses, they will have what’s called homologous structures.  

 

And what that means is that they’re developed from the same embryological tissue. They have very similar function, structure and location. So in men and women, the head of the penis and the clitoris develop from the same tissues.  

 

As well as the hood of the clitoris and the foreskin of the penis. And then we look at the lips of the labia or the outer and inner lips of the vagina. And the scrotum is actually analogous or similar to the outer lips of the vagina, and that’s called the Labia majora.  

 

So everything you see in this picture is called the vulva. And then at the top, very top, you see the clitoris. And that is, again, as I mentioned, mentioned analogous to the male penis, the head of the penis.  

 

And so it’s full of tons of nerve endings. And very commonly stimulation of the clitoris will result in orgasm for women similar to how men need penal stimulation to have orgasms as well. It has a hood as well.  

 

 

And you can see that’s called the prep use. The prep use can be covering the clitoris, can be moved back and forth similar to the foreskin of the penis. 

 

Interestingly, sometimes the hood of the clitoris can actually get adhesions or stuck to the top of the clitoris.  

 

And in some people, this can cause some pain. Before we move on to the other anatomy, let’s get a little bit deeper into the clitoris. 

 

Interestingly, the word clitoris is actually derived from the Greek word Kliettoris or kleis, which means key by which one enters the door.  

 

 

Very interesting, the clitoris is exactly identical embryologically to the penis, the head and the shaft of the penis. And while it looks pretty small and you only see a very small part of the clitoris when you actually look at the entire internal part of the clitoris and here you can see a picture, it’s actually quite long and bifurcates very similar to how the erectile tissue of the penis does.  

And in fact, when you look at studies where they’ve actually done anatomical dissections, it is identical to the nerve and the blood vessels to the penis. Similar to the penis, the clitoris can also get enlarged and engorged with blood during an erection and have twomescents very similar to what happens during an erection in a male.  

And I describe that in my article about sildenafil and tadalafil, if you want to learn a little bit more about what happens during an erection for a man. 

 

 

And here you can see that all of this erectile tissue covers the urethral opening and the vaginal opening and goes out to the sides.  

 

So that is also right underneath some of the inner lips of the vagina or the labia minora. And so some people can find those areas to be very sensitive as well. 

 

Below the clitoris, you can see the urethral opening.  

 

The urethral opening is essentially at the end of your p tube. So your bladder makes urine, and it pees out of that p tube. Below that, you can see the vagina itself. 

 

The vagina is a pretty amazing structure.  

 

The reason being is that it can change in shape. As you may know, when women have babies, it can get quite large to have the passage of a baby. But similarly, that’s what happens during arousal. During arousal, it actually gets wider and longer, up to three inches longer, when the person is aroused.  

 

And then last, below all that you can see the opening to the anus. In women, we always talk about having three holes, the urethra, which is at the very top, then the vagina, and last, the anus. So as I mentioned throughout this video, the clitoris is analogous to the penis. 

 

So many, many women need clitoral stimulation in order to orgasm. 

 

But a lot of people talk about this thing called the G-⁠spot. 

 

So what exactly is the G-⁠spot? 

 

It was actually identified in 1940 by Ernst Grafenburg.  

 

It’s on the top of the vagina, or what we call the anterior wall of the vagina, about an inch or two inside the vagina. A lot of people describe this as you can feel or find this area by putting. Finger in the vagina and using a come hither motion.  

 

However, it’s not like a magic button that you can actually find and press. It’s just an area where there’s lots and lots of nerves. Interestingly, right above the vagina in this area is what we call the skins gland, and the skins gland is analogous or homologous to the male prostate. 

 

I’ve previously talked about prosthetic massage and how some people find this to be pleasurable, and similarly, some women may find massage of this area to be pleasurable as well. 

 

However is this,The Holy grail. Well, for some women, they are able to orgasm with penetration to the G-⁠spot. But for most women, clitoral stimulation is required for orgasm to happen, because, like I’ve described in this entire article, the clitoris is basically the same sensitivity, the same tissue structure as the male penis.  

 

And so women need clitoral stimulation very often in order to reach orgasm. I hope you guys enjoyed this introduction to female anatomy. 

 

In my next article on female sexual health, I’m going to be talking about female ejaculation. 

 

So make sure you subscribe and don’t miss that one. And as always, we’re going to take care of yourself.
